citeinfo.title: RI Forest Health Works Project: Points All Invasives
citeinfo.othercit: Suggested bibliographic reference: RIGIS, 2012. Rhode Island Forest Health Works Project: Points. Rhode Island Geographic Information System (RIGIS) Data Distribution System, URL: http://www.rigis.org, Environmental Data Center, University of Rhode Island, Kingston, Rhode Island (last date accessed: 16 June 2012).

citeinfo.title: Rhode Island Geographic Information System (RIGIS) Data Distribution System

descript.abstract:
The Forest Health Works Project (FHWP), a partnership between the Rhode Island Natural History Survey (RINHS) and the Rhode Island Department of Environmental Management (RIDEM), conducted rapid inventories for invasive plants in selected areas across Rhode Island. Details are available in the Forest Health Works Project final report, available by contacting the Rhode Island Natural History Survey. The dataset described by this metadata record represents GPS locations of photo points and invasive plant communities 20 ft in diameter or smaller documented by the FHWP.
The purpose of this dataset is to represent how invasive plant species are distributed throughout core forested areas and other selected areas in Rhode Island. It was used by the FHWP in determining where invasive plant treatment would occur. This dataset is intended for use by the public.
descript.purpose: This dataset represents how invasive plant species are distributed throughout core forested areas and other selected areas in Rhode Island. It was used by the FHWP in determining where invasive plant treatment would occur.
descript.supplinf: The Forest Health Works Project final report is available by contacting the Rhode Island Natural History Survey.

Private land depicted representative of invasive plant species on a particular property does not indicate public access to that site.

attracc.attraccr: All GIS data were individually cross-checked against field data (paper datasheets) and other QAQC procedures were followed to insure both spatial and attribute consistency and accuracy. During the QAQC process fewer than 5% of the records had errors. All known errors were corrected.

procstep.procdesc: The FHWP GIS database of invasive species represents 2 1/2 years of field work mapping invasives in the state of Rhode Island. The field work was conducted by Rhode Island Natural History Survey scientists. The mapping was done using points, lines, and polygons. All field mapping was done using a Garmin GPSMap 60CSx GPS device and a field notebook. The "FHWP_pts_all" file is a point dataset of GPS locations that represents photo points and invasive plant communities 20 ft in diameter or smaller. Stands larger than 20 ft in diameter were mapped as a polygon and as individual species (ACPL_NorwayMaple, e.g.). The "FHWP_tracks_all" file represents a bread-crumb trail of the areas surveyed by field crews. All GPS data were intersected on the 2008 e911 Pictometry statewide imagery. Stands (polygons) were mapped by heads-up digitizing in ArcMap using GPS locations as guide and 2008 aerial photography as a base map. At the beginning of the project, a database schema was developed to insure attribute conformity. All GIS data were individually cross-checked against field data (paper datasheets) and other QAQC procedures were followed to insure both spatial and attribute consistency and accuracy. During the QAQC process fewer than 5% of the records had errors. All errors were corrected. Details for how these invasive plant species data were developed may be found the in the FHWP final report. This report is available online at "http://rinhs.org/who-we-are-what-we-do/programs-projects/fhwp" or by directly contacting the Rhode Island Natural History Survey. Contributors to and developers of these data include Mike Bradley, James Barnes, Hope Leeson, Grace Lentini, and Jackie VanSant.

Data contributed to RIGIS by the Rhode Island Natural History Survey. Data exported from a flat geodatabase to individual shapefiles. Metadata reviewed, content updated in partnership with FHWP staff, minor corrections made to formatting, RIGIS distribution information added.

enttyp.enttypd: This is a point data set of an invasive plant species mapped by the FHWP during the 2010 field season
